Award.AwardTitle: RUI: The Role of Facial Physiognomy in Stereotypic Trait Inference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Until somewhat recently, consideration of target-level differences among category members figured surprisingly little into theorizing about stereotyping. Rather, social psychologists have focused almost solely on category membership as the basis for stereotyping, essentially disregarding within-category differences. Over the past decade, however, researchers have begun to examine how differences in physical features (e.g., skin tone, nose shape, etc.) among people who share a category membership may contribute to our understanding of stereotyping -- a form of stereotyping that has been referred to as feature-based stereotyping. The effect of feature-based stereotyping is nontrivial; researchers have evidenced that features may unduly influence prison sentence lengths, capital punishment decisions, and police officers' decision to shoot over and above the influence of categories.

The goal of the proposed research is to study whether and how differences in facial physiognomy predict our judgments of others over and above category membership alone. The current research project consists of 3 phases. In Phase 1, the researchers will build a database of over 500 faces, each rated on a number of dimensions (stereotypic, threatening, masculine, feminine, baby-faced, attractive, trustworthy, happy, angry, sad, disgusted, surprised, fearful/afraid, and unusual). This database will be made freely available to any investigator interested in using these stimuli for research purposes and will afford significant time and resource savings to others. In Phase 2, the researchers will test the robustness of feature-based stereotyping by testing whether or not more typical features activate stereotypes more readily, across different social groups, different features, and different stereotyped characteristics.
Finally, Phase 3 will investigate the process by which features influence trait judgments. The researchers will test whether the influence of features is mediated through categorization -- a supposition that is has been central to decades of stereotyping research -- or, whether features can bypass categorization and directly activate stereotypes, as some have recently proposed.

The research will both enhance scientific infrastructure by developing an important set of facial stimuli for researchers and also advance the current understanding of the processes that govern stereotyping. Moreover, the research will facilitate the training of undergraduate and graduate students at a predominantly undergraduate and Hispanic-serving institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The role of facial physiognomy figures prominently in psychological research. For example, stereotyping researchers have recently shown that facial features can influence our judgments of others over and above category membership alone. Based on this work, researchers have proposed a novel form of stereotyping referred to as feature-based stereotyping. The research conducted with the support of this grant has advanced our understanding of how precisely features related to judgments like stereotyping and prejudice. Indeed, the relationship appears to be more complex than was previously described. Understanding precisely how features influence judgment is of critical significance if we are to effectively combat harmful stereotypes and prejudice. In addition to the theoretical contributions we were able to make in the domain of feature-based judgments, the work done with the aid of this funding has allowed us to offer a significant resource to the scientific community. One of the chief outcomes of our research was the development of a public database of facial stimuli (Chicago Face Database; www.chicagofaces.org). The Chicago Face Database contains high-resolution images of almost 600 males and females from different racial categories, as well as extensive norming data and physical measurements of the faces. Since 2015, the database has been downloaded by over 4,000 researchers across many disciplines and around the world, providing a clear testament to its usefulness to scientists and the need for such a resource. The Chicago Face Database has been cited by over 40 published papers in its brief existence and is arguably the most comprehensive database of facial stimuli in the world for high-resolution, standardized stimuli. It has also seriously advanced the kinds of questions that researchers studying face perception and impression formation (stereotyping and prejudice) researchers can ask. Using this resource, we were able to model the features that facilitate racial categorization and we are currently exploring how variation between and within racial categories might explain important and consequential phenomena like the cross-race recognition deficit.
